children.subject: thanks a lot for such a thorough guide! it really helped me a lot. Also, having experience in this field, what upper division cs classes would recommend for this particular area?

So I should clarify that this is my perspective towards quant research roles that are more of a data science-y type of work, i.e.  hunting for signals for asset pricing and such. For this kind of role, 126/127/189 are typically good choices. In addition, Stat 215A is also quite a good class for this stuff as a more applied stats/ML class. 227B/227C are also good classes but they are often quite difficult to get in as an undergrad.

If you want to focus more on the low latency stuff, ignore the course recommendations above and take the low-level and systems classes, i.e. 151/152/162/164. Although you should take my opinion here with a grain of salt, as I am not in this specific area

Honestly a second major doesn't help you that much for finding a job, just make sure you take the classes that gives you the best preparation for the interviews and the job. Some pretty good examples outside of the EECS departments are classes like Stat 135/151A/153, Econ 141.

Classes that helped me in particular when I was job hunting were courses like Stat 210A/B since there are quite a few former Berkeley PhDs working at these companies and they understand the difficulty of these classes, and as well classes in the math department such as 104 and 202 since analysis is known to be a difficult topic. However I wouldn't recommend you to take these classes just for the sake of looking good; the classes mentioned previously should be more than sufficient.

Something else that also helped me was having research with professors: people who work in quantitative finance are quite familiar with members of the ML community so having some sort of research with famous professors can really help, especially if they are a professor that typically does not work with undergrads. I had a recruiter tell me that my second round was entirely a formality and I was guaranteed an onsite because of the research I was doing with a particular professor.
